catalyst.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to renewable hydrocarbon fuels is a promising strategy to address global energy issues; however, producing fuels like CH 4 is highly challenging under visible light.In this work, fabrication of a two-dimensional bentonite (2D-Bt) nanosheet mediated WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 Z-scheme heterojunction for highly selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to CH 4 under visible light has been investigated.The photocatalytic performance of the newly developed WO 3 -embedded 2D pillared Bt with 2D g-C 3 N 4 composite for selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to methane was studied using H 2 O as the reducing agent under visible light.WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 (WBCN) exhibits the highest photocatalytic activity for CH 4 production, which was 6.01, 6.76, and 25.30 times higher than using WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , and g-C 3 N 4 samples, respectively.Noticeably, WO 3 -coupled with g-C 3 N 4 was favorable for CO production; however, introducing Bt layered clay was in favor of methane formation during the CO 2 reduction process.Additionally, the Z-scheme of the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite with Bt as the electron moderator could promote photoinduced charge separation and redox ability of the separated charge carriers, resulting in excellent CO 2 reduction to CH 4 .The rate of reaction was dependent only on the external mass transfer due to surface reactions over the WBCN composite catalyst.With increasing photon flux, methane production was further enhanced due to the thermodynamically favorable process for the activation of CO 2 methanation reaction.Besides, good cycling ability was observed due to the presence of a layered clay structure, which was sustained in multiple cycles without obvious deactivation.This study provides a green clay based noble-metal-free approach to construct a structured composite photocatalyst with a Z-scheme charge carrier and would be beneficial for CO 2 reduction and other solar energy applications.

reaction medium.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to renewable hydrocarbon fuels is a promising strategy to address global energy issues; however, producing fuels like CH 4 is highly challenging under visible light.In this work, fabrication of a two-dimensional bentonite (2D-Bt) nanosheet mediated WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 Z-scheme heterojunction for highly selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to CH 4 under visible light has been investigated.The photocatalytic performance of the newly developed WO 3 -embedded 2D pillared Bt with 2D g-C 3 N 4 composite for selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to methane was studied using H 2 O as the reducing agent under visible light.WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 (WBCN) exhibits the highest photocatalytic activity for CH 4 production, which was 6.01, 6.76, and 25.30 times higher than using WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , and g-C 3 N 4 samples, respectively.Noticeably, WO 3 -coupled with g-C 3 N 4 was favorable for CO production; however, introducing Bt layered clay was in favor of methane formation during the CO 2 reduction process.Additionally, the Z-scheme of the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite with Bt as the electron moderator could promote photoinduced charge separation and redox ability of the separated charge carriers, resulting in excellent CO 2 reduction to CH 4 .The rate of reaction was dependent only on the external mass transfer due to surface reactions over the WBCN composite catalyst.With increasing photon flux, methane production was further enhanced due to the thermodynamically favorable process for the activation of CO 2 methanation reaction.Besides, good cycling ability was observed due to the presence of a layered clay structure, which was sustained in multiple cycles without obvious deactivation.This study provides a green clay based noble-metal-free approach to construct a structured composite photocatalyst with a Z-scheme charge carrier and would be beneficial for CO 2 reduction and other solar energy applications.

reducing agent in a fixed bed and gas-phase photoreactor system.WO 3 / Bt/g-C 3 N 4 exhibits excellent photoactivity for both CO and CH 4 productions during the CO 2 photoreduction process under visible-light irradiation.The highest yields of CO and CH 4 of 37.4 and 118.9 mol h -1 were obtained using 150 mg of photocatalyst under 20 mW cm -2 light intensity.The amount of CH 4 production over the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite was 5.98-, 6.74-, and 25.19-fold higher than its production over WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , and g-C 3 N 4 samples, respectively.The production of CO and CH 4 over the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite varied by using different amounts of catalyst loading, providing information that interaction between light irradiation and catalyst is very important to maximize photocatalytic activity.The production rate of CH 4 was increased to 177.9 mol h -1 using 100 mW cm -2 light intensity under the same reaction conditions.A 1.49-fold improvement in performance of the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite was observed by increasing light intensity from 20 to 100 mW cm -2 due to more production of charge carriers over the composite photocatalyst surface.Highest QYs of 20.106 and 1.875 for CH 4 and CO were achieved over the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite with a selectivity of 72.82 for methane formation.In general, the significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance of the composite catalyst was due Energy Fuels to the formation of the direct Z-scheme system with higher redox potential for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 under visible-light irradiation.The stability analysis further confirms continuous fuel formation over entire irradiation time and employing multiple cycles without any decrement in productivity.The findings of the present work are expected to be utilized for constructing the Z-scheme heterojunction system without using noble metals with controlled morphology for tailoring photoinduced CO 2 reduction to fuels and which would also be helpful for other solar fuel application.
